body: I couldn't get that last commit to squash... not sure why.  Probably just my numpty git.

Just started reviewing this. There's a lot here, so it's not going to make the cut into 1.7, but it looks basically good.

There's some cosmetic stuff:
- Rebase and squash into a single commit
- Make sure all comments are real, not stuff like "/*\* */" to shut up checkstyle.
- Try to comply with the coding style. Indent 2, continuation indent 4; don't align parameters/arguments with the opening '(', just indent them 4. (E.g. revert the formatting change you made to RelCollationTraitDef.canConvert.)
- Make sure "mvn javadoc:javadoc javadoc:test-javadoc" passes under both jdk 1.7 and 1.8. (It doesn't right now.)
- Remove '// implement Interface' comments; we don't use them in new code
- Use "{@link ...}" when you reference a class or method in javadoc. It forces us to make references stay up-to-date.

I'm running some exhaustive tests and reviewing the content more thoroughly and should have some more feedback soon.
One more: add the new tests to CalciteSuite.
This ended up fixed by the Drill guys and I never got chance to fully implement it, so I'll close it.
Looks like one of the tests is failing on JDK8.

Thanks!  I will make the suggested changes.  I did have a question about a test "JdbTest.testJoinManyWay".

It looks like when there are enough joins, this patch slows things down significantly.  In particular, I believe 4 way join is fine, but when I get to 6 way joins, the test seems to run for a long time (I have never finished 6-way join with this patch).  I think, with JoinCommuteRule and this patch together, the planning may become excessively thorough/exhaustive.  For example, if I remove this patch, or make JoinCommuteRule.onMatch() to return before calling transformTo(), the 6-way join returns within 10 seconds or so.

I will be looking into this a little bit, but wanted to see if any of you have suggestions/ideas to fix this issue.  I could file this problem in a separate issue and debug it separately but wanted to make this a known problem before proceeding.

Thanks!
Minji

Well, JAAS-configuration-file-based login is causing me loads of heartburn on JDK8, and I have no idea why.

```
    [GSS LoginConfigImpl]: Trying com.sun.security.jgss.krb5.accept: does not exist.
    [GSS LoginConfigImpl]: Trying com.sun.security.jgss.accept: does not exist.
    [GSS LoginConfigImpl]: Cannot read JGSS entry, use default values instead.
    [LoginContext]: login success
    [LoginContext]: commit success
Found KeyTab Default keytab
Entered Krb5Context.acceptSecContext with state=STATE_NEW
Looking for keys for: HTTP/localhost@EXAMPLE.COM
Looking for keys for: HTTP/localhost@EXAMPLE.COM
2016-03-23 00:39:28,813 [qtp841262455-34] WARN  -
GSSException: Failure unspecified at GSS-API level (Mechanism level: Invalid argument (400) - Cannot find key of appropriate type to decrypt AP REP - AES128 CTS mode with HMAC SHA1-96)
```

For some reason, it just does not want to read the entries in the JAAS file, and thus can't find the key for the principal. At least, that's the best I can understand at this point.

Interestingly, switching surefire to `forkMode=always` nets a success:

```
    [GSS LoginConfigImpl]: Trying com.sun.security.jgss.krb5.accept: Found!
Debug is  true storeKey true useTicketCache false useKeyTab true doNotPrompt false ticketCache is null isInitiator false KeyTab is /Users/jelser/projects/calcite.git/avatica/server/target/HttpServerSpnegoWithJaasTest_keytabs/HTTP_localhost.keytab refreshKrb5Config is true principal is HTTP/localhost@EXAMPLE.COM tryFirstPass is false useFirstPass is false storePass is false clearPass is false
Refreshing Kerberos configuration
Java config name: /Users/jelser/projects/calcite.git/avatica/server/target/HttpServerSpnegoWithJaasTest/krb5.conf
Loaded from Java config
>>> KdcAccessibility: reset
principal is HTTP/localhost@EXAMPLE.COM
Will use keytab
    [LoginContext]: login success
Commit Succeeded

    [LoginContext]: commit success
Found KeyTab /Users/jelser/projects/calcite.git/avatica/server/target/HttpServerSpnegoWithJaasTest_keytabs/HTTP_localhost.keytab for HTTP/localhost@EXAMPLE.COM
```

Something from the `AvaticaSpnegoTest.java` must be screwing something up. I've yet to figure out what exactly that is though.

Continuing on my previous comment about JdbTest.testJoinManyWay.  It looks like I had commented out one of the test (I was trying to see how many way join we could do).  I will upload again with a new set of changes.

For example, 
-  join-6-way takes about 10-15 seconds without this patch (ran it on calcite master)
-  join-4-way takes 70 seconds with this patch.  I tried to do 6-way join, but was taking too long.

@julianhyde @jacques-n Any suggestion as to how I can debug the many-way-join issue?  I will be working on this next.

One thing that @jacques-n had suggested was to include an option that will enable RelCollationTrait/DistributionTrait conversion in "the middle of the tree", so that any users that do not need it won't pay the performance penalty.

To debug the planner, use the log4j.logger.org.apache.calcite.plan.RelOptPlanner flag, per https://calcite.apache.org/docs/howto.html#tracing. When the planner is taking too long it is very difficult to debug because the planning process is holistic, i.e. there is no particular line of code to blame.

These queries more intensive planner effort than any others in the suite but they are definitely not outliers. They highlight a serious concern that will show up in other complex queries.

I think @jacques-n's idea of enabling conversion "in the middle of the tree" is a good one. (Do you mean "in the middle of the planning process", i.e. switching them on at a particular time? Or do you mean enabling the strategy on nodes that are close to the leaves?) If the former, I'm a big believer that real queries need multi-phase optimization with different rules & strategies enabled.
Wasn't there a pull request for CALCITE-1177 also? If so, I can't find it anymore. We can't commit CALCITE-1177 until there is a new Avatica release so it's important that pull request stays open.

There is no PR for CALCITE-1177 yet. The changes I referred in the JIRA are in my repo: https://github.com/vkorukanti/calcite/commits/CALCITE-1177. I will submit a PR once we have new Avatica release.
Hi @julianhyde, could you please review this PR?
Ah, you're right. I noticed your CALCITE-1177 branch when I was committing CALCITE-1179. I was mistaken that there was a PR for it.

@julianhyde there was a change I made in Driver. We were actually creating multiple Service instances per Connection. I'd appreciate any feedback how to handle that -- I'm not 100% happy with what I created now stylistically, but it's functional.

@wjsl I'd appreciate if you could take a look at the KerberosUtil code. I know you've been working on Kerberos login stuff w/o Hadoop's UGI in the picture.

I think you should rename hsqldb-server. It happens to use hsqldb, but it would serve its purpose if it used a different database. We don't want people thinking that we intend this to be a good, fully featured, server for hsqldb. That is not its purpose.

The doc doesn't define TCK directly enough. The goal is that if you have implemented an Avatica provider, the TCK will try to kick holes in it, and help you improve the quality of your server faster.

I know I've said it before, but the doc could be more direct. Use active voice, not passive. Present tense, not future. And it's a bit too apologetic about missing functionality.

Why do we need do bundle hsqldb?

> I think you should rename hsqldb-server. It happens to use hsqldb, but it would serve its purpose if it used a different database

Good point. Maybe something like standalone-server? The original point was that it would create a "runnable" jar.

> The doc doesn't define TCK directly enough. The goal is that if you have implemented an Avatica provider, the TCK will try to kick holes in it, and help you improve the quality of your server faster.

Ok, I'll reread what I put on the website with this in mind and see what else I can come up with.

> Why do we need do bundle hsqldb?

Not sure which direction you're coming from with this. If it's from a "why hsqldb?": it could be any database like you say. Or, if it from a "why bundle it?": the intent was to have a standalone artifact that is always available for a release to run Avatica against. If someone files a bug against 1.8.0 and says a 1.8.0 client doesn't work with a 1.6.0 server, I want to be able to easily launch an instance of Avatica 1.6.0 server without having to worry about the integration with some other system (e.g. Phoenix, Drill, etc). Ultimately, we can own it and make it as simple as possible.

I have no problem with the choice of hsqldb; in fact, I use hsqldb as the basis of sqlline's test suite, for very similar reasons.

It's the "bundling" I am concerned about. Judging by the LICENSE file you are including it in the distribution. Why is this necessary? The TCK is a development-time tool, so you don't need to bundle the binaries that it needs.

> It's the "bundling" I am concerned about. Judging by the LICENSE file you are including it in the distribution. Why is this necessary?

Yes, there is a shaded jar in which HSQLDB is included in. This goes to the 2nd point -- I do not want to make starting a server for testing any harder than it needs to be. Thankfully, HSQLDB is BSD licensed which makes it simple for us to include it and, to the first point, agnostic to the user/dev.

> The TCK is a development-time tool, so you don't need to bundle the binaries that it needs.

IMO, it's necessary because if we make it harder to run, no one will run it. I feel that even now, having to start a server for each version you want to test now is a wart. Having a single JAR file that can be referenced to run a server was an trivial first step to make running this framework easier (lets us punt on bootstrapping all of the necessary servers for the time-being -- long term, I can see a project which fully automates the TCK).
Thanks for this. We can't depend on snapshots, so we'll take this patch after avatica-1.8.0 but before calcite-1.8.0.

Hello @michaelmior , Can you kindly review this PR as well? Apart from documentation, do I need to provide anything else for the initial contribution?

As is already suggested in Jira, we may need to enhance the adapter with more new features.

I think there's more than enough here feature-wise to warrant inclusion. I took a skim over the code and it looks more complete than the Cassandra adapter was when that first got merged :) I think adding the documentation should cover everything.

@julianhyde Should we be aiming to get this in for the 1.8 release?

@michaelmior This feature would be half-baked if we rushed it into 1.8. Better to take our time, make sure the architecture, tests and doc are solid before we launch. If the base is solid, it will be easy to add new features (just like you have been doing to the Cassandra adapter recently).
@julianhyde Agreed. I thought it might be worth considering since this PR looks in great shape, but there's really no need to rush things.

@julianhyde @jacques-n I have made some additional changes so that the join planning is just as efficient as before.  With the latest changes, each Convention gets to decide whether it wants to handle trait conversions using AbstractConverters (e.g. Collation, Distribution, etc.).  By default, all the Convention returns false to using AbstractConverters.  So, everything should be just as fast as before.  The 6-way join completes within 14 seconds, which is what we were seeing earlier without this change.

I ran all the tests in calcite and they all passed.  Please review and send me any more comments that you may have.  Thanks!  -Minji

We probably need the change in [1]. Otherwise, the output field names will not in the same ordinal position.

Try  field name list "EMPID, EMPID,  abc".  Uniqify() might return "abc, EMPID, EMPID0".

This looks good, and I'm just about to commit it.

In future can you use `assertThat` rather than `assertEquals` or `assertTrue`. The following will produce a confusing message because you have mixed up `expected` and `actual`:

```
assertEquals(leastRestrictive.getSqlTypeName(), SqlTypeName.NULL);
```

it's easier to get it right with `assertThat`:

```
assertThat(leastRestrictive.getSqlTypeName(), is(SqlTypeName.NULL));
```
Thanks, @julianhyde.  I will use assertThat from now on.

I don't think this is a bug in ReduceExpressionRule. It's a bug in your code. The expressions in a Project must not have a call to AS in them. (AS is meaningless once the SQL has been translated and column names have been determined.)

It's reasonable that RelBuilder.project should strip AS calls out of expressions, but I don't think LogicalProject.create should do that.

Closing https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1295 as invalid. Can you close this PR?

As discussed in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1297, this patch does not give the right behavior. After providing an identity project that renames fields, RelBuilder should not create an identity project, but for the purposes of the {{RelBuilder.field}} methods the field should have the new name. Plus, the patch needs to add test cases.
Fixed in 240cee4.
Yes, I will close it. This issue can be fixed by CALCITE-1297.

Hi @julianhyde , I have updated this PR. Can you have a look again? 

Additionally, I'm confused that why `Frame.right` is a List with only one Pair in it all the time ?
A join has two named inputs, and the output is the concatenation of the fields from the left with the fields from the right. In this case, Frame.right would have two elements.

The purpose of RelBuilder is to eventually obsolete factories for particular kinds of RelNode. Do we need those extra arguments?
I wanted to pass in the filter/project factories into RelOptUtil, which creates the rel nodes, so that I get the right type of new filter/project nodes.  Should I use the RelBuilder instead?

Every time a rule needs to create a new kind of RelNode we have to add a new parameter, and deprecate the old method. That gets really tiresome. Also, the factories themselves are not able to optimize, say removing redundant predicates from a filter. So, we are phasing out factories. If you want to  use a specific ProjectFactory, create a RelBuilder with that specific factory inside it. It shouldn't be difficult to take an existing RelBuilder and create one that is identical but just uses a given ProjectFactory.
Sure, I will.

SqlUnParserTest fails because of the spurious `(` ... `)` around `LATERAL`. I solved it by adding `LATERAL` to the list in `SqlKind.EXPRESSION`. (Yeah, that's a pretty subtle one.)

Your work looks really good. The one thing you haven't dealt with is the scoping rules: a LATERAL table can see every table BEFORE it in the FROM clause, but not itself or tables AFTER it in the FROM clause. I tidied up some stuff, added some tests, and pushed a branch https://github.com/julianhyde/calcite/tree/1309-lateral-table. I added `SqlValidatorTest.testCollectionTableWithLateral2` to illustrate the scoping problem. Can you fix it?

Hi @julianhyde , I fixed the scope problem. But the SqlUnparserTest still fail, it still throws the following exception:

```
java.lang.AssertionError: Received error while parsing SQL 'SELECT *
FROM "DEPT",
LATERAL(TABLE("RAMP"("DEPT"."DEPTNO")))'; error is:
org.apache.calcite.sql.parser.SqlParseException: Encountered "TABLE (" at line 3, column 9.
Was expecting one of:
```

Could you help have a look again ?
Maybe change SqlKind to make TABLE a non-expression just like LATERAL?

Hi  @julianhyde,  the TABLE(actually is COLLECTION_TABLE) has been in the non-expression list. So maybe it's not the cause of the problem.  I find that the `(` `)` around `TABLE` is because LATERAL do unparse as a function syntax.

So I fixed it by changing the way of LATERAL `unparse` to make sure no parenthesis generated around `TABLE`. Could you review this PR again ?

Can you change the commit description to something the user would understand? Users don't know about AvaticaSite.

One final thing: I did correct your commit message. Here in Calcite/Avatica, we use the form "[JIRA_ID] message", e.g. "[CALCITE-1371] fix setDate with Calendar in AvaticaSite". If you can remember to follow this next time, that would be nice.

Thanks a lot. I will follow the rules.

I think you should have used the JIRA description "PreparedStatement does not process Date type correctly" for the commit description rather than "fix setDate with Calendar in AvaticaSite". The latter is what you did, but the user reading the commit log is more interested in the problem that was fixed. Also, for contributions from non-committers we append the contributor name.

Can you please update you site https://github.com/bluejoe2008/solr-sql and change the first mention of "Calcite" to "Apache Calcite"? Calcite is an Apache trademark.

The most recent commit addresses all my comments about the code.

We still need to discuss time-zones. If the application is running in (say) Pacific time and stores a zoneless timestamp value "1970-01-01 00:00:00" in the database, then we will send it to Druid as if they had said "1970-01-01 00:00:00Z" (see https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2619), and that is incorrect. We can't possibly know what timezone the application is interpreting its date in.

+1 to commit the code as it stands, and let's discuss timezone in a different thread. Let's discuss on https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1357 and maybe it will become a new JIRA case.
@julianhyde I see you were doing some work here, but I can't seem to find the PR review that Github claims was made :) Anything I can help out with?

For reference, origin issue is from Apache Storm: https://github.com/apache/storm/pull/1714
We would like to support nested Map with type & runtime safety.

With this patch, 1 level access of map and array works without applying CAST to value.
In 2 levels (nested) access of map, if first level of value is null (key not found), it throws NullPointerException at runtime.
I'm now trying to see why this respects that any operands of item can be nullable. Please help me if you have an idea why this happens.

Type definition of FOO:

```
.field("ID", SqlTypeName.INTEGER)
.field("MAPFIELD",
        typeFactory.createTypeWithNullability(
                typeFactory.createMapType(
                        typeFactory.createTypeWithNullability(
                                typeFactory.createSqlType(SqlTypeName.VARCHAR), true),
                        typeFactory.createTypeWithNullability(
                                typeFactory.createSqlType(SqlTypeName.INTEGER), true))
                , true))
.field("NESTEDMAPFIELD",
        typeFactory.createTypeWithNullability(
            typeFactory.createMapType(
                    typeFactory.createTypeWithNullability(
                            typeFactory.createSqlType(SqlTypeName.VARCHAR), true),
                    typeFactory.createTypeWithNullability(
                            typeFactory.createMapType(
                                    typeFactory.createTypeWithNullability(
                                            typeFactory.createSqlType(SqlTypeName.VARCHAR), true),
                                    typeFactory.createTypeWithNullability(
                                            typeFactory.createSqlType(SqlTypeName.INTEGER), true))
                            , true))
                        , true))
.field("ARRAYFIELD", typeFactory.createTypeWithNullability(
        typeFactory.createArrayType(
            typeFactory.createTypeWithNullability(
                typeFactory.createSqlType(SqlTypeName.INTEGER), true), -1L)
        , true))
```

Query:

```
SELECT ID, MAPFIELD['c'], NESTEDMAPFIELD, ARRAYFIELD 
FROM FOO 
WHERE NESTEDMAPFIELD['b']['c'] = 2 AND ARRAYFIELD[2] = 200
```

Generated code for where statement:

```
  final Object[] current = context.values;
  final java.util.Map v = (java.util.Map) org.apache.calcite.runtime.SqlFunctions.mapItem((java.util.Map) current[2], "b");
  final boolean v0 = (Integer) org.apache.calcite.runtime.SqlFunctions.mapItem(v, "c") == null;
  final java.util.List inp3_ = (java.util.List) current[3];
  final boolean v3 = (Integer) org.apache.calcite.runtime.SqlFunctions.arrayItem(inp3_, 2) == null;
  outputValues[0] = (v0 || ((Integer) org.apache.calcite.runtime.SqlFunctions.mapItem(v, "c")).intValue() == 2) && (v3 || ((Integer) org.apache.calcite.runtime.SqlFunctions.arrayItem(inp3_, 2)).intValue() == 200) ? (v0 || v3 ? (Boolean) null : Boolean.TRUE) : Boolean.FALSE;
```

v0 is null checked but v is not checked at all.

I had been digging above and found there's no support on nullable AbstractSqlType.
SqlTypeFactoryImpl.createTypeWithNullability() doesn't handle AbstractSqlType overriding its nullability. Is there other way to define SQL type field to nullable?
